rule_content.description: Design exceptions based on how callers will handle them. Create exception types based on caller's needs, use special case objects for predictable failures, and wrap third-party exceptions at boundaries.

do.description: Design exceptions based on how they will be handled
content: Create exception types based on caller's needs
Use special case objects for predictable failures

dont.description: Don't create exception hierarchies by component only

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Every piece of knowledge should have a single, authoritative representation (DRY principle). Extract repeated logic into reusable functions and use abstraction to capture common patterns.

do.description: Eliminate duplication through abstraction and reuse
content: Extract repeated logic into reusable functions
Use abstraction to capture common patterns
Apply DRY principle to both code and data
Create shared utilities for common operations

- Tests verify behavior, not implementation details

dont.description: Don't copy-paste code or maintain multiple versions of same logic

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Hide implementation details and expose minimal interface. Make fields private by default, expose behavior not data, and follow Law of Demeter (principle of least knowledge).

do.description: Hide implementation details behind clean interfaces
content: Expose behavior through methods, not raw data
Follow Law of Demeter (principle of least knowledge)

dont.description: Don't use getters/setters as glorified public fields
content: Don't use getters/setters as glorified public fields
Don't return references to mutable internal state

rule_content.description: Formatting should be consistent and automated. Agree on formatting rules as a team, use automated formatters (prettier, black, gofmt), and enforce formatting in CI/CD pipeline.

rule_content.description: Open for extension, closed for modification. Design for extension without modification, depend on interfaces/abstractions not concrete types, and use composition over inheritance.

rule_content.description: When refactoring public interfaces, provide migration paths to avoid breaking existing code. Maintain backward compatibility during transitions and deprecate old interfaces gracefully.

Deprecate old interface with warnings (not immediate removal)

dont.description: Don't break existing code without migration path

1. Add new interface alongside old one

rule_content.description: Keep error handling separate from business logic. Extract try/catch blocks into dedicated functions and handle errors at appropriate abstraction levels.

content: Extract try/catch blocks into dedicated functions

Keep business logic clean and focused

content: Wrap third-party APIs behind your interfaces

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Each class should have one reason to change. Keep classes cohesive (methods/data interdependent), focus on single responsibility, and extract multi-responsibility classes.

do.description: Keep classes focused on single responsibility
content: Keep classes cohesive (methods and data interdependent)
Extract multi-responsibility classes into separate classes
Each class has ONE reason to change
- Class methods all serve same purpose
- Class data all related to same concept
- Class has one reason to change
- High cohesion: methods use most instance variables

dont.description: Don't create god objects doing everything
content: Don't keep private methods used by only few methods
- Class has many methods doing unrelated things
- Low cohesion: methods use different subsets of instance variables
- Extract each responsibility into separate class
- Each class focused on ONE responsibility

rule_content.description: Classes should be small and free of dead code. Keep classes under 200-300 lines, eliminate dead/unused code, and favor many small classes over few large ones.

do.description: Keep classes small and focused
content: Favor many small classes over few large ones
Each class should be easy to understand
- Each class focused on single responsibility

dont.description: Don't let classes grow without bounds or keep dead code
content: Don't let classes grow without bounds
Don't mix multiple languages in one source file

- Mixed languages (SQL, HTML, etc. in source)
- Extract related methods into separate classes
- Remove all commented-out code (it's in git)
- Extract embedded languages to separate files

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Functions should do one thing and do it well, with no hidden side effects. Each function must have a single, well-defined responsibility.

do.description: Keep functions focused on a single task
content: Functions should do one thing and do it well
Extract multiple concerns into separate functions
Name functions to reveal their complete behavior
Make side effects explicit in function names
- Function validates input → separate from function that processes it
- Function calculates result → separate from function that logs/saves it
- Function reads data → separate from function that transforms it
- All code in function serves same purpose
- Function name clearly describes its complete behavior
- No hidden side effects (logging, I/O, mutations)

dont.description: Don't mix business logic with side effects or multiple operations
content: Don't mix business logic with side effects (logging, I/O, mutations)
Don't create functions that perform multiple unrelated operations
Don't hide side effects in function implementations
- Function that validates AND saves data (split into validate() and save())
- Function that calculates AND logs result (split into calculate() and log())
- Function that reads AND transforms data (split into read() and transform())
- Function has AND in its name (calculateAndSave, validateAndProcess)
- Function performs I/O while doing calculations
- Function modifies state while returning values
- Does this function do ONE thing?
- Can I split this into smaller, focused functions?
- Does the function name reveal ALL its behavior?

rule_content.description: Functions should be small enough to understand at a glance. Keep functions under 20 lines when possible and extract complex logic into named helper functions.

do.description: Keep functions small and focused
content: Keep functions under 20 lines when possible
Extract complex logic into named helper functions
Use descriptive names that eliminate need for comments
Make each function a single abstraction level
- Small function calls 3-4 well-named helper functions
- Complex calculation split into named steps
- Nested logic extracted to separate functions
- Easy to understand at a glance
- Easy to reuse in other contexts

dont.description: Don't create large, monolithic functions
content: Don't mix abstraction levels within a single function
Don't keep dead (unused) functions in the codebase
- Function mixing high-level logic with low-level details
- Function with multiple nested loops and conditionals
- Function has deeply nested blocks (3+ levels)
- Function needs comments to explain sections
- Function is hard to name clearly
- Extract each logical section into named function
- Use guard clauses to reduce nesting
- Create helper functions for complex conditions
- Separate high-level orchestration from low-level details

rule_content.description: Code should flow from high-level concepts down to details. Follow 'newspaper metaphor' (high-level first), keep related functions close together, and step down one abstraction level at a time.

do.description: Maintain consistent abstraction levels
content: Step down one abstraction level at a time
Each function should stay at single abstraction level
- High level: processOrder(order) calls validateOrder, calculateTotal, saveOrder
- Mid level: validateOrder(order) calls checkInventory, validatePayment
Each function reads like prose at its abstraction level

dont.description: Don't mix low-level details with high-level concepts
content: Don't mix low-level details with high-level concepts
Don't jump between abstraction levels randomly
Don't scatter related logic across file
- Function mixes high-level operations with low-level details
- Direct database/file access in business logic functions
- String manipulation mixed with business operations
- Infrastructure code mixed with domain code
- Extract low-level details into separate functions
- Create intermediate functions for mid-level operations
- Keep each function at single abstraction level
- Organize code top-down: high → mid → low
- Reader should be able to drill down gradually

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Tests should be as clean as production code. Keep tests readable and maintainable, use descriptive test names, and follow FIRST principles (Fast, Independent, Repeatable, Self-validating, Timely).

do.description: Keep tests clean and maintainable
content: - Independent: Tests don't depend on each other

test('calculates order total including tax and shipping', () => {
- Test code as clean as production code

dont.description: Don't let test code decay or skip tests
content: Don't make tests dependent on each other

rule_content.description: Related code should be visually close. Group related concepts together, declare variables close to usage, and keep files under 500 lines when possible.

do.description: Keep related code close together
content: Keep files under 500 lines when possible
Use vertical spacing to separate concepts

dont.description: Don't separate related code or declare variables far from usage
content: Don't separate related code with blank lines

- Blank lines between tightly related statements
- Move variable declarations near first use
- Split large files into smaller modules

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Prefer immutable data structures and pure functions. Use immutable data structures by default, create new objects instead of mutating, and make immutability explicit in type system.

do.description: Use immutable data structures and pure functions
content: Use immutable data structures by default
Create new objects instead of mutating existing ones
Make immutability explicit in type system (const, final, readonly)
Favor pure functions that don't mutate state

dont.description: Don't mutate shared global state or function parameters
content: Don't use mutable variables when const/final works
- let result; if (x) result = 1; else result = 2; // use const with ternary
- Direct property assignment on shared objects
- Mutating arrays/collections in place (push, splice, etc.)
- Use array methods: map, filter, concat (not push, splice)
- Use const by default, let only when necessary
- Create new objects instead of modifying
- Pass copies if mutation is unavoidable

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Never swallow exceptions silently. Empty catch blocks hide failures and make debugging impossible. Always log, handle, or rethrow exceptions with context.

do.description: Always handle exceptions properly - log, rethrow, or take corrective action
content: Always handle exceptions - never ignore them
Log exceptions with full context before recovering
Rethrow exceptions if you can't handle them properly
Wrap and rethrow with additional context
Take corrective action if you can recover
- try { risky_operation() } except Exception as e: logger.error(f'Operation failed: {e}', exc_info=True); raise
- try { process() } catch (e) { console.error('Process failed:', e); throw e; }
- try { save() } catch (e) { logger.error('Save failed:', e); return fallback_value; }
- try { connect() } catch (ConnectionError as e) { logger.warning('Retry attempt', e); retry(); }
- ALWAYS log the exception with full stack trace
- Include context: what operation failed, relevant IDs/data
- Rethrow if you can't handle it properly
- Use finally blocks for cleanup (close files, connections)
- Document why you're catching and what recovery is
- You can take meaningful corrective action
- You need to clean up resources (use finally)
- You need to add context and rethrow
- You're at a boundary (API, UI) and need to translate
- You can't do anything useful with it
- You don't know how to handle it
- It should cause the operation to fail

dont.description: NEVER swallow exceptions with empty catch blocks
content: NEVER catch and ignore without logging
NEVER catch Exception without specific reason
NEVER suppress errors to 'make it work'
- try { risky_operation() } catch (e) { } // WRONG: Silent failure
- try { process() } except: pass // WRONG: Hiding errors
- try { save() } catch { return; } // WRONG: Ignoring failure
- try { connect() } catch (Exception e) { /* TODO: handle */ } // WRONG: Empty handler
- try { load() } except Exception: continue // WRONG: Silently skipping errors
- Generic catch-all without logging: except Exception:
- Hides bugs and makes debugging impossible
- Creates silent failures users don't know about
- Data corruption when errors are ignored
- Production issues with no error logs
- Log the exception with full context
- Rethrow if you can't handle it: raise or throw e
- Take corrective action if recovery is possible
- Use finally for cleanup, not catch for ignoring
- Document WHY you're catching and what you're doing
- If you must catch-all, log and rethrow
- try { optional_feature() } catch (e) { logger.info('Optional feature unavailable', e); // explicitly documented as optional }
- Even then: ALWAYS log why you're ignoring it

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Write tests before production code. Write failing test first (Red), write minimal code to pass (Green), refactor with confidence (Refactor). This is the Red-Green-Refactor cycle.

do.description: Follow Test-Driven Development cycle
content: Repeat cycle for each new behavior

dont.description: Don't write tests after code is done or skip refactoring

Don't make code too hard to test

rule_content.description: Express intent in code first, comments second. Rename variables/functions instead of commenting, extract methods to make intent clear, and use comments only when code can't express intent.

rule_content.description: Names should provide appropriate context without redundancy. Use longer names for longer scopes and replace magic numbers with named constants.

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: When refactoring, replace old code completely - don't try to support both legacy and new patterns. Write new code, delete old code, fix tests. Clean breaks are better than compatibility bridges that create technical debt.

do.description: Replace old pattern completely with new pattern
content: When refactoring, commit fully to the new approach
Delete old code completely, don't leave it around
Update all call sites to use new pattern
Fix all tests to work with new code
Clean break is better than supporting both ways
1. Write new code with better pattern
2. Update all call sites to use new code
4. Update tests to match new implementation
STEP 2: Update ALL action methods to use template
STEP 3: Delete old duplicated code from each method
- Clean codebase with one clear pattern
- No confusion about which approach to use
- No technical debt from compatibility code
- Easy to understand for future developers

dont.description: Don't try to support both old and new patterns simultaneously
content: Don't create compatibility layers for old code
Don't support both old and new ways of doing things
Don't leave old code around 'just in case'
Don't add conditional logic to support legacy patterns
Don't incrementally migrate - do complete refactor
# Support both old way (logic function) and new way (action class)
# Now we have to maintain both paths!
# Some actions still use old pattern (inconsistent!)
- Two ways to do the same thing (confusion)

- Have one clear way to do things

- Major version transition with migration period

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: When refactoring production code, update tests immediately to maintain green builds. Tests should verify behavior, not implementation details, so they remain valid through refactoring.

content: Update tests as you refactor production code

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Separate pure logic from side effects and infrastructure. Keep pure calculations separate from I/O, isolate business logic from infrastructure, and separate queries from commands.

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Most comments are useless. Kill AI-generated docstrings that just repeat function names and parameters. Only write comments for complex non-obvious algorithms, business rules, warnings, or legal notices. If the code is clear, NO COMMENT NEEDED.

do.description: ONLY write comments for complex algorithms, business rules, warnings, or legal notices
content: DEFAULT: NO COMMENT - Let the code speak for itself

dont.description: KILL all useless AI-generated docstrings and obvious comments

Make function names encode parameter meaning
- calculateTotal(items) instead of calculateTotal(item1, item2, item3)
- createUser({name, email, role}) instead of createUser(name, email, role, active, verified)
- sendEmail(message) where message contains all email data
- 0 parameters: Ideal (pure function or uses instance state)
- 1 parameter: Very good (single input, single output)
- Return values instead of output parameters

dont.description: Don't use boolean flags or excessive parameters
content: Don't use boolean flags as parameters (create two functions instead)
Don't exceed 3 parameters without using a parameter object
Don't use output parameters (return values instead)
- process(data, true, false) → unclear what booleans mean
- createUser(name, email, role, active, verified, age, phone) → too many params
- calculate(input, result) where result is modified → use return value
- Boolean flags indicating different behaviors → split into two functions
- More than 3 parameters → create parameter object
- Output parameters → return values or use immutable approach
- Unclear parameter order → use named parameters/object
- create(a, b, c, d, e) → create({a, b, c, d, e})

rule_content.description: Use consistent, meaningful indentation. Use 2-4 spaces consistently (or tabs if team prefers), indent to show code structure, and keep lines under 80-120 characters.

do.description: Use consistent indentation to show structure
content: Use 2-4 spaces consistently (or tabs if team prefers)

dont.description: Don't mix tabs and spaces or create extremely long lines
content: const result = someFunction(param1, param2, param3, param4, param5, param6, param7, param8, param9, param10); // too long!
- Set editor to use spaces (not tabs) or consistent tabs
- Break long lines into multiple lines:

rule_content.description: Use one word per concept across the entire codebase. Pick consistent terms (get/fetch/retrieve → choose one) and follow domain language for business concepts.

do.description: Maintain consistent naming patterns across codebase
content: Pick one term per concept (get/fetch/retrieve → choose one)
Use consistent naming patterns for similar operations
Follow domain language for business concepts
Establish team conventions and stick to them
- Always use 'get' for retrieval: getUser, getOrder, getProduct
- Always use 'create' for new entities: createUser, createOrder
- Domain terms consistent: Customer (not Client in some places, Customer in others)
- One word per concept throughout codebase
- Same operation = same verb (get, fetch, retrieve → pick one)
- Same concept = same noun (user, account, member → pick one)
- Follow established conventions in existing code

dont.description: Don't mix synonyms or use different names for same abstraction
content: Don't mix synonyms for the same concept
Don't use different names for same abstraction
Don't encode type information in names (Hungarian notation)
- Mixing: getAccount(), fetchUser(), retrieveOrder() (pick one verb)
- Hungarian: strName, intAge, boolActive (type in name)
- fetch* for async/network retrieval (or use get consistently)
- find* for queries that may not find

rule_content.description: Prefer exceptions over error codes for exceptional conditions. Use exceptions for truly exceptional situations, provide informative error messages, and create domain-specific exception types.

do.description: Use exceptions for exceptional situations
content: Use exceptions for truly exceptional situations
Provide informative error messages with context
Include relevant data in exception objects
- throw new InvalidOrderException('Order missing required items', {orderId, items})
- Use for truly exceptional conditions (not normal flow)
- Provide context: what, why, relevant data
- Create specific exception types for different failures
- Don't expose sensitive data in messages

dont.description: Don't use exceptions for normal control flow or return error codes
content: Don't use exceptions for normal control flow
Don't return error codes from modern APIs
- try { user = findUser(); } catch { user = createUser(); } // normal flow
- return -1; // error code instead of exception
- Exceptions for expected conditions (empty array, null result)
- Reserve exceptions for truly exceptional cases

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Make dependencies visible through constructor injection. Pass dependencies through constructors, make all dependencies explicit and visible, and use dependency injection for flexibility.

do.description: Make dependencies explicit and inject them
content: Make all dependencies explicit and visible
Use dependency injection for flexibility and testability
- Clear what class needs to function

dont.description: Don't use hidden global state or create dependencies inside classes
content: Don't create dependencies inside classes (new Database())
- Static method calls to external services
- No constructor parameters despite external dependencies
- Move all 'new' calls out of class
- Replace singleton access with injected interface
- Make every external dependency a constructor parameter
- Use dependency injection container for wiring

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Names should clearly communicate purpose and usage. Use names that answer 'why does this exist?' and make them searchable and pronounceable.

do.description: Use names that reveal intent and purpose
content: Use names that answer 'why does this exist?'
Choose names that reveal the problem domain
Use full words instead of abbreviations
- Name can be spoken naturally in conversation
- Name can be easily searched in codebase

dont.description: Don't use cryptic, abbreviated, or unclear names
content: Don't use single-letter names (except loop counters in tiny scopes)
Don't rely on mental mapping or cryptic abbreviations
Don't use cute or clever names that obscure meaning
- d, x, temp, data (what are they?)
- Single letters (except i, j in small loops)
- Can I explain this variable in conversation without showing code?
- Would a new team member understand this name?
- Does this name reflect domain language?
- Can I search for this name effectively?

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Most comments are useless. Kill AI-generated docstrings that just repeat function names and parameters. Only write comments for complex non-obvious algorithms, business rules, warnings, or legal notices. If the code is clear, NO COMMENT NEEDED.

do.description: ONLY write comments for complex algorithms, business rules, warnings, or legal notices
content: DEFAULT: NO COMMENT - Let the code speak for itself
- Complex non-obvious algorithms (explain WHY this approach)
- Business rules with external references (policy, regulation)
// Business Rule: Orders over $1000 require manager approval per SEC regulation 2024-05
// WARNING: O(n^2) complexity. Use spatial index for >1000 points.
// Dijkstra's algorithm - we need shortest path, not just connectivity
// Copyright (c) 2024 Company Name. Licensed under MIT.
- Explain WHY (never WHAT - code shows what)
- Explain algorithm choice (why Dijkstra not BFS?)
Test: Can you delete the comment and still understand the code?
- If NO → Keep it (but first try improving the code)

dont.description: KILL all useless AI-generated docstrings and obvious comments
content: KILL these immediately - they add ZERO value:
- Docstrings that repeat function name and parameters
- AI-generated parameter descriptions that just restate the name
- Comments that describe WHAT code does (code already shows this)
- Attribution or change history (git has this)
(USELESS - just repeats signature, adds zero information)
- 'This function does X' when function name is do_x
- 'Gets/Sets X' when method name is get_x/set_x
- 'Returns the X' when return type already clear
- If code unclear, IMPROVE THE CODE (rename, extract, simplify)
- Only add comment if TRULY complex or non-obvious
- Can you understand the code without the comment? → DELETE IT
- Would renaming make the comment unnecessary? → RENAME, DELETE COMMENT
- Is the comment just AI filler? → DELETE IT

rule_content.description: Design exceptions based on how callers will handle them. Create exception types based on caller's needs, use special case objects for predictable failures, and wrap third-party exceptions at boundaries.

do.description: Design exceptions based on how they will be handled
content: Create exception types based on caller's needs
Use special case objects for predictable failures
Group similar failures into single exception type if handled same way
- class NullUser extends User { ... } // special case object
- Exception type reflects how caller handles it
- Wrap third-party exceptions to avoid leaking dependencies
- Use special case pattern for predictable null/empty cases

dont.description: Don't create exception hierarchies by component only
content: Don't create exception hierarchies by component/type only
Don't force callers to handle many similar exception types
(if caller handles all same way, use single DatabaseException)
- Catching SQLException throughout codebase (leak third-party type)
- 20 different exception types caller must handle individually
- Exception hierarchy based on technical components
- Third-party exceptions used directly in business logic
- Callers forced to catch many similar exceptions
- Group exceptions by how caller handles them
- Use special case objects instead of null checks
- Reduce exception types caller must know about

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Every piece of knowledge should have a single, authoritative representation (DRY principle). Extract repeated logic into reusable functions and use abstraction to capture common patterns.

do.description: Eliminate duplication through abstraction and reuse
content: Extract repeated logic into reusable functions
Use abstraction to capture common patterns
Apply DRY principle to both code and data
Create shared utilities for common operations
- Extract patterns: createResource(type, data) handles all resources
- Each concept has single source of truth
- Tests verify behavior, not implementation details
- Common test assertions → create verification helpers (verify_*)
- Test data creation → create builders or test_helpers

dont.description: Don't copy-paste code or maintain multiple versions of same logic
content: Don't maintain multiple versions of same logic
- Same validation logic copied to 5 different functions
- Similar but slightly different functions (updateUser, updateAccount, updateProfile)
- Repeated patterns (createUser, createOrder, createProduct with identical structure)
- Same business rules in multiple locations
- Identical error handling in many functions
- Repeated test setup across test files
- Same assertion patterns in multiple tests
- Extract common logic into shared functions
- Create base classes or mixins for shared behavior
- For tests: Create test_helpers.py with verification functions
- For tests: Use fixtures for repeated setup
- For tests: Extract test data builders

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Hide implementation details and expose minimal interface. Make fields private by default, expose behavior not data, and follow Law of Demeter (principle of least knowledge).

do.description: Hide implementation details behind clean interfaces
content: Expose behavior through methods, not raw data
Follow Law of Demeter (principle of least knowledge)
- No direct access to internal state
- Law of Demeter: only talk to immediate friends

dont.description: Don't use getters/setters as glorified public fields
content: Don't use getters/setters as glorified public fields
Don't return references to mutable internal state
Don't chain method calls through multiple objects
getItems() { return this.items; }  // exposing mutable state
setItems(items) { this.items = items; } // public field disguised
- Getters/setters for every field (just use public fields)
- Instead of getItems(), provide addItem(), removeItem()
- Instead of getTotal(), calculate internally when needed
- Return defensive copies if must return collections
- Focus on BEHAVIOR not data access

rule_content.description: Formatting should be consistent and automated. Agree on formatting rules as a team, use automated formatters (prettier, black, gofmt), and enforce formatting in CI/CD pipeline.

do.description: Use automated, consistent formatting
content: Agree on formatting rules as a team
Use automated formatters (prettier, black, gofmt, rustfmt)
Configure formatter in project (no manual formatting)
- CI/CD fails if code not formatted
- Team agrees on style guide once
- No formatting debates in code reviews
- Style is consistent across entire codebase

dont.description: Don't have formatting wars or manual formatting
content: Don't have 'formatting wars' in code reviews
Don't let individual preferences override team standards
- Manual formatting changes in every commit
- Configure editor to format on save
- Add pre-commit hook or CI check

rule_content.description: Open for extension, closed for modification. Design for extension without modification, depend on interfaces/abstractions not concrete types, and use composition over inheritance.

do.description: Design classes open for extension, closed for modification
content: Depend on interfaces/abstractions, not concrete types
// Can extend with new processors without modifying OrderService
- New behavior through new classes, not modifying existing
- Depend on abstractions (interfaces) not concrete classes
- Use polymorphism instead of if/switch on type

dont.description: Don't hardcode dependencies on concrete classes
content: Don't hardcode dependencies on concrete classes
Don't let derived classes leak into base classes
// Must modify this code to add new payment type!
- Must modify existing code to add new behavior
- Base class knows about derived classes
- Use strategy pattern for varying algorithms

rule_content.description: When refactoring public interfaces, provide migration paths to avoid breaking existing code. Maintain backward compatibility during transitions and deprecate old interfaces gracefully.

do.description: Provide backward compatibility during interface changes
content: Add new attribute alongside old one during migration
Deprecate old interface with warnings (not immediate removal)
Document migration path in code comments
Give users time to migrate (deprecation period)
self.bot_name = bot_name  # Keep old name for compatibility
def getUserData(self, user_id):  # Old name - deprecated
warnings.warn('getUserData is deprecated, use get_user_data', DeprecationWarning)
- Old interface still works during migration period
- Clear deprecation warnings with migration guidance
- Major version bump for breaking changes (semver)

dont.description: Don't break existing code without migration path
content: Don't rename/remove public interfaces without compatibility layer
Don't remove deprecated interfaces too quickly
Don't forget to document breaking changes
# BAD: Renamed attribute breaks all existing code
self.name = bot_name  # Old code expects self.bot_name!
# All existing code calling getUserData() breaks!
# def old_method():  # Just deleted - breaks everything!
1. Add new interface alongside old one
2. Add deprecation warnings to old interface
5. Remove old interface in major version bump
6. Document in CHANGELOG and migration guide

rule_content.description: Keep error handling separate from business logic. Extract try/catch blocks into dedicated functions and handle errors at appropriate abstraction levels.

do.description: Separate error handling from business logic
content: Extract try/catch blocks into dedicated functions
Handle errors at appropriate abstraction levels
Write tests for error scenarios first
Keep business logic clean and focused
- Business logic functions: focus on happy path
- Wrapper functions: handle errors and orchestrate
- Error boundary functions: catch, log, transform
- Each layer handles errors appropriate to its level

dont.description: Don't mix error handling with business logic
content: Don't mix error handling with business logic
Don't propagate checked exceptions through many layers
Don't leave error handling as an afterthought
// business logic mixed with error handling
- Try/catch blocks scattered throughout business logic
- Error handling interrupting main logic flow
- Extract business logic to pure functions
- Keep core logic error-free (let exceptions bubble)
- Use higher-order functions for error handling patterns

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Don't let external APIs spread through your codebase. Wrap third-party APIs behind your interfaces, create learning tests for external dependencies, and isolate boundary code from business logic.

do.description: Isolate third-party code behind your interfaces
content: Wrap third-party APIs behind your interfaces
Create learning tests for external dependencies
Isolate boundary code from business logic
Limit third-party API exposure to boundary layer
send(to: string, subject: string, body: string): Promise<void>;
async send(to: string, subject: string, body: string) {
await this.sendGridClient.sendEmail({ to, subject, html: body });
// Business logic depends on YOUR interface
- Business logic independent of third-party changes

dont.description: Don't pass third-party types through your functions
content: Don't pass third-party types between your functions
Don't let external APIs dictate your design
Don't skip learning tests for dependencies
function createUser(userData: Auth0User) { // Auth0 type leaked
- External API calls scattered throughout codebase
- Business logic coupled to specific libraries
- Changing library requires changing many files
- Create interface defining what YOU need
- Use YOUR types in business logic
- Write learning tests for third-party behavior

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Each class should have one reason to change. Keep classes cohesive (methods/data interdependent), focus on single responsibility, and extract multi-responsibility classes.

do.description: Keep classes focused on single responsibility
content: Keep classes cohesive (methods and data interdependent)
Extract multi-responsibility classes into separate classes
Each class has ONE reason to change
- Class methods all serve same purpose
- Class data all related to same concept
- Class has one reason to change
- High cohesion: methods use most instance variables

dont.description: Don't create god objects doing everything
content: Don't keep private methods used by only few methods
- Class has many methods doing unrelated things
- Low cohesion: methods use different subsets of instance variables
- Extract each responsibility into separate class
- Each class focused on ONE responsibility

rule_content.description: Classes should be small and free of dead code. Keep classes under 200-300 lines, eliminate dead/unused code, and favor many small classes over few large ones.

do.description: Keep classes small and focused
content: Favor many small classes over few large ones
Each class should be easy to understand
- Each class focused on single responsibility

dont.description: Don't let classes grow without bounds or keep dead code
content: Don't let classes grow without bounds
Don't mix multiple languages in one source file
- Hundreds of lines of commented-out code
- File with SQL strings, HTML templates, and business logic
- Mixed languages (SQL, HTML, etc. in source)
- Extract related methods into separate classes
- Remove all commented-out code (it's in git)
- Extract embedded languages to separate files
- Prefer 5 classes of 100 lines over 1 class of 500 lines
- Use composition to combine small classes

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Functions should do one thing and do it well, with no hidden side effects. Each function must have a single, well-defined responsibility.

do.description: Keep functions focused on a single task
content: Functions should do one thing and do it well
Extract multiple concerns into separate functions
Name functions to reveal their complete behavior
Make side effects explicit in function names
- Function validates input → separate from function that processes it
- Function calculates result → separate from function that logs/saves it
- Function reads data → separate from function that transforms it
- All code in function serves same purpose
- Function name clearly describes its complete behavior
- No hidden side effects (logging, I/O, mutations)

dont.description: Don't mix business logic with side effects or multiple operations
content: Don't mix business logic with side effects (logging, I/O, mutations)
Don't create functions that perform multiple unrelated operations
Don't hide side effects in function implementations
- Function that validates AND saves data (split into validate() and save())
- Function that calculates AND logs result (split into calculate() and log())
- Function that reads AND transforms data (split into read() and transform())
- Function has AND in its name (calculateAndSave, validateAndProcess)
- Function performs I/O while doing calculations
- Function modifies state while returning values
- Does this function do ONE thing?
- Can I split this into smaller, focused functions?
- Does the function name reveal ALL its behavior?

rule_content.description: Functions should be small enough to understand at a glance. Keep functions under 20 lines when possible and extract complex logic into named helper functions.

do.description: Keep functions small and focused
content: Keep functions under 20 lines when possible
Extract complex logic into named helper functions
Use descriptive names that eliminate need for comments
Make each function a single abstraction level
- Small function calls 3-4 well-named helper functions
- Complex calculation split into named steps
- Nested logic extracted to separate functions
- Easy to understand at a glance
- Easy to reuse in other contexts

dont.description: Don't create large, monolithic functions
content: Don't mix abstraction levels within a single function
Don't keep dead (unused) functions in the codebase
- Function mixing high-level logic with low-level details
- Function with multiple nested loops and conditionals
- Function has deeply nested blocks (3+ levels)
- Function needs comments to explain sections
- Function is hard to name clearly
- Extract each logical section into named function
- Use guard clauses to reduce nesting
- Create helper functions for complex conditions
- Separate high-level orchestration from low-level details

rule_content.description: Code should flow from high-level concepts down to details. Follow 'newspaper metaphor' (high-level first), keep related functions close together, and step down one abstraction level at a time.

do.description: Maintain consistent abstraction levels
content: Step down one abstraction level at a time
Each function should stay at single abstraction level
- High level: processOrder(order) calls validateOrder, calculateTotal, saveOrder
- Mid level: validateOrder(order) calls checkInventory, validatePayment
Each function reads like prose at its abstraction level

dont.description: Don't mix low-level details with high-level concepts
content: Don't mix low-level details with high-level concepts
Don't jump between abstraction levels randomly
Don't scatter related logic across file
- Function mixes high-level operations with low-level details
- Direct database/file access in business logic functions
- String manipulation mixed with business operations
- Infrastructure code mixed with domain code
- Extract low-level details into separate functions
- Create intermediate functions for mid-level operations
- Keep each function at single abstraction level
- Organize code top-down: high → mid → low
- Reader should be able to drill down gradually

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Tests should be as clean as production code. Keep tests readable and maintainable, use descriptive test names, and follow FIRST principles (Fast, Independent, Repeatable, Self-validating, Timely).

do.description: Keep tests clean and maintainable
content: - Independent: Tests don't depend on each other
- Repeatable: Tests work in any environment
- Timely: Tests written at right time (before production code)
test('calculates order total including tax and shipping', () => {
- Test code as clean as production code

dont.description: Don't let test code decay or skip tests
content: Don't make tests dependent on each other

rule_content.description: Related code should be visually close. Group related concepts together, declare variables close to usage, and keep files under 500 lines when possible.

do.description: Keep related code close together
content: Keep files under 500 lines when possible
Use vertical spacing to separate concepts
const items = order.items;           // declare near use
const discount = order.discount;     // declare near use

dont.description: Don't separate related code or declare variables far from usage
content: Don't separate related code with blank lines
Don't put variables far from their usage
- Variables declared at top, used 100 lines later
- Blank lines between tightly related statements
- Move variable declarations near first use
- Split large files into smaller modules

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Prefer immutable data structures and pure functions. Use immutable data structures by default, create new objects instead of mutating, and make immutability explicit in type system.

do.description: Use immutable data structures and pure functions
content: Use immutable data structures by default
Create new objects instead of mutating existing ones
Make immutability explicit in type system (const, final, readonly)
Favor pure functions that don't mutate state
- Easier to reason about code behavior

dont.description: Don't mutate shared global state or function parameters
content: Don't use mutable variables when const/final works
- let result; if (x) result = 1; else result = 2; // use const with ternary
- Direct property assignment on shared objects
- Mutating arrays/collections in place (push, splice, etc.)
- Use array methods: map, filter, concat (not push, splice)
- Use const by default, let only when necessary
- Create new objects instead of modifying
- Pass copies if mutation is unavoidable

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Never swallow exceptions silently. Empty catch blocks hide failures and make debugging impossible. Always log, handle, or rethrow exceptions with context.

do.description: Always handle exceptions properly - log, rethrow, or take corrective action
content: Always handle exceptions - never ignore them
Log exceptions with full context before recovering
Rethrow exceptions if you can't handle them properly
Wrap and rethrow with additional context
Take corrective action if you can recover
- try { risky_operation() } except Exception as e: logger.error(f'Operation failed: {e}', exc_info=True); raise
- try { process() } catch (e) { console.error('Process failed:', e); throw e; }
- try { save() } catch (e) { logger.error('Save failed:', e); return fallback_value; }
- try { connect() } catch (ConnectionError as e) { logger.warning('Retry attempt', e); retry(); }
- ALWAYS log the exception with full stack trace
- Include context: what operation failed, relevant IDs/data
- Rethrow if you can't handle it properly
- Use finally blocks for cleanup (close files, connections)
- Document why you're catching and what recovery is
- You can take meaningful corrective action
- You need to clean up resources (use finally)
- You need to add context and rethrow
- You're at a boundary (API, UI) and need to translate
- You can't do anything useful with it
- You don't know how to handle it
- It should cause the operation to fail

dont.description: NEVER swallow exceptions with empty catch blocks
content: NEVER catch and ignore without logging
NEVER catch Exception without specific reason
NEVER suppress errors to 'make it work'
- try { risky_operation() } catch (e) { } // WRONG: Silent failure
- try { process() } except: pass // WRONG: Hiding errors
- try { save() } catch { return; } // WRONG: Ignoring failure
- try { connect() } catch (Exception e) { /* TODO: handle */ } // WRONG: Empty handler
- try { load() } except Exception: continue // WRONG: Silently skipping errors
- Generic catch-all without logging: except Exception:
- Hides bugs and makes debugging impossible
- Creates silent failures users don't know about
- Data corruption when errors are ignored
- Production issues with no error logs
- Log the exception with full context
- Rethrow if you can't handle it: raise or throw e
- Take corrective action if recovery is possible
- Use finally for cleanup, not catch for ignoring
- Document WHY you're catching and what you're doing
- If you must catch-all, log and rethrow
- try { optional_feature() } catch (e) { logger.info('Optional feature unavailable', e); // explicitly documented as optional }
- Even then: ALWAYS log why you're ignoring it

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: Write tests before production code. Write failing test first (Red), write minimal code to pass (Green), refactor with confidence (Refactor). This is the Red-Green-Refactor cycle.

do.description: Follow Test-Driven Development cycle
content: Repeat cycle for each new behavior

dont.description: Don't write tests after code is done or skip refactoring
content: Don't write tests after code is done
Don't make code too hard to test
2. Add tests afterwards to hit coverage targets
3. Tests hard to write because code not designed for testing
4. Skip refactoring because tests already pass
- Code hard to test (too many dependencies)
- Start with test, even if simple
- If code hard to test, that's a design smell

rule_content.description: Express intent in code first, comments second. Rename variables/functions instead of commenting, extract methods to make intent clear, and use comments only when code can't express intent.

do.description: Express intent through clear code
content: Extract methods to make intent clear
Use comments only when code can't express intent
Self-documenting code is better than commented code
BAD: // check if employee is eligible for benefits
- Public API documentation for external users
- Business rules that can't be expressed in code
- Example: SCENARIO: User checkout flow with 3% discount

dont.description: Don't use comments to explain bad code
content: Don't use comments to explain bad code
Don't add noise comments stating the obvious
- Comments stating what code obviously does
- Comments that just repeat function names
- Extract complex logic to named functions
- Use descriptive names instead of comments

rule_content.description: Names should provide appropriate context without redundancy. Use longer names for longer scopes and replace magic numbers with named constants.

do.description: Provide appropriate context in names
content: Use longer names for longer scopes
Add contextual prefixes when clarifying relationships
Replace magic numbers with named constants
- In small scope: email (context is obvious)
- Context added when needed, not when obvious

dont.description: Don't add gratuitous context or leave magic numbers unexplained
content: Don't add gratuitous context that's obvious from structure
Don't use meaningless distinctions (data1, data2, dataInfo)
- accountUserEmailAddress (redundant 'account' if already in Account class)
- Remove redundant context from class members

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: When refactoring, replace old code completely - don't try to support both legacy and new patterns. Write new code, delete old code, fix tests. Clean breaks are better than compatibility bridges that create technical debt.

do.description: Replace old pattern completely with new pattern
content: When refactoring, commit fully to the new approach
Delete old code completely, don't leave it around
Update all call sites to use new pattern
Fix all tests to work with new code
Clean break is better than supporting both ways
1. Write new code with better pattern
2. Update all call sites to use new code
4. Update tests to match new implementation
STEP 2: Update ALL action methods to use template
STEP 3: Delete old duplicated code from each method
- Clean codebase with one clear pattern
- No confusion about which approach to use
- No technical debt from compatibility code
- Easy to understand for future developers

dont.description: Don't try to support both old and new patterns simultaneously
content: Don't create compatibility layers for old code
Don't support both old and new ways of doing things
Don't leave old code around 'just in case'
Don't add conditional logic to support legacy patterns
Don't incrementally migrate - do complete refactor
# Support both old way (logic function) and new way (action class)
# Now we have to maintain both paths!
# Some actions still use old pattern (inconsistent!)
- Two ways to do the same thing (confusion)
- More code to maintain and test
- Harder to reason about system behavior
- Future developers don't know which pattern to follow
- Tests may pass but codebase is messy
- Fix all tests to match new pattern
- Have one clear way to do things
- External API with many consumers you don't control
- Major version transition with migration period

rule_content.description: CRITICAL: When refactoring production code, update tests immediately to maintain green builds. Tests should verify behavior, not implementation details, so they remain valid through refactoring.

do.description: Update tests in parallel with production refactoring
content: Update tests as you refactor production code
Use test helpers to abstract common test patterns
Update test imports when moving code
- Create BaseAction → Update all action tests to use it
- Move methods between classes → Update test imports immediately
- Change folder structure → Update ALL import statements in tests
- Extract helper function → Update tests to use helper
- Create test_helpers.py → Consolidate duplicate test code
- Tests pass after each production change
- Test helpers eliminate test code duplication
- Test names remain clear and descriptive
- Tests run fast (no slow integration tests unless needed)

dont.description: Don't let tests break during refactoring or depend on implementation details
content: Don't refactor production without updating tests
Don't leave broken tests 'to fix later'
Don't make tests depend on implementation details
- Refactor production → 20 tests fail → 'will fix later'
- Create BaseAction → Tests still expect old class structure
- Move file → Tests can't import it → Build broken
- Change method signature → Tests still use old signature
- Duplicate test setup code across files

rule_content.description: When production code breaks, ALWAYS follow the test-first workflow: write/modify failing test, verify failure, fix code, verify success, then test in production. Never fix bugs directly without a failing test first.
rationale: Writing a failing test before fixing a bug ensures: (1) we can reproduce the bug, (2) we know when it's truly fixed, (3) we prevent regression, (4) we document the bug for future reference.
Skipping the failing test step means we might fix the wrong thing or not really fix it at all.
A failing test proves we understand the bug and can reproduce it. Without this, we're guessing at the fix.
If the test doesn't fail, either: (a) we're testing the wrong thing, (b) the bug doesn't exist in test environment, (c) the test is wrong. We must know the test fails before proceeding.
Minimal fixes reduce risk of introducing new bugs. If more changes are needed, they should be separate commits with their own tests.
A fix in one area might break something else. Running the full test suite catches regressions immediately.
Production testing is expensive (time, risk). Never waste time testing in production until automated tests confirm the fix works.
Tests that pass but don't prevent production failures are worse than no tests - they give false confidence. The test must be improved to catch what production caught.
Tests serve as documentation. Future developers should understand what bug was fixed by reading the test.

key_principles: WHEN production code breaks, ALWAYS write or modify a test to reproduce the bug FIRST
ALWAYS run the test BEFORE fixing to confirm it fails for the RIGHT reason
Make the MINIMAL change to fix the bug - just enough to make the test pass
Run ALL related tests after the fix to ensure no regression
ONLY AFTER tests pass, test the fix in production/real environment
If fix works in tests but fails in production, the test is INCOMPLETE - return to step 1
Document the bug and fix in the test name and test scenario
RED: Write/modify test to reproduce bug (test fails)
GREEN: Make minimal fix to pass the test
PRODUCTION: Test in real environment only after automated tests pass
antipatterns: Fix first, test later - Can't prove the fix actually solves the problem. Might fix wrong thing. No way to verify it stays fixed.
Skip verifying test fails before fixing - Test might be wrong or testing the wrong thing. You'll make unnecessary changes or miss the real bug.
Test only in production - Wastes time (restart servers, wait for changes). Risky (might break production). No automation (will break again).
Make large changes while fixing bug - Can't tell if the bug fix worked or if new code introduced new bugs. Mixing refactoring with bug fixes leads to confusion.
Fix code without improving test when production still fails - Tests that pass but don't prevent production failures are worse than no tests - they give false confidence.
Use generic test names - Future developers can't understand what bug was fixed by reading the test
workflow: 1. RED: Write/modify test to reproduce bug (test fails)
2. Verify test fails for the right reason
3. GREEN: Make minimal fix to pass the test
5. Run full test suite (verify no regression)
6. PRODUCTION: Test in real environment (MCP server, actual usage)
7. If production still fails: repeat from step 1 with better test

[ ] Confirmed test fails for the RIGHT REASON (not a test bug)

[ ] Run test - VERIFIED it now passes
[ ] Run FULL test suite - VERIFIED no regressions
[ ] Test in production/real environment
[ ] If production still fails, repeat from step 1 with better test

decision_criteria.description: Decision making criteria for code behavior

criteria.question: How should the code be organized into layers or architectural components?
criteria.outcome: Determines code structure, separation of concerns, and module organization
options: Layered architecture - Domain, Service, Presentation, Data layers
Hexagonal/Ports and Adapters - Core domain with adapters for external concerns
Clean Architecture - Entities, Use Cases, Interface Adapters, Frameworks
Domain-Driven Design - Services, Aggregates, Context Boundaries, Entities, Value objects, Repositories, Factories, Events, Rules, UI
Simple module structure - Functions and classes organized by feature
MVC/MVP/MVVM - Model-View separation patterns
Microservices structure - Independent services with clear boundaries
Monolithic structure - Single module with clear internal organization
Business Logic Only- pure business logic classes focused on modeling both properties and behavior

criteria.question: How should dependencies be managed and injected?
criteria.outcome: Determines how components depend on each other and external systems
options: Constructor injection - All dependencies passed through constructors
Dependency injection container - Use DI framework for dependency management
Factory pattern - Use factories to create dependencies
Service locator - Central registry for dependencies
Minimal dependencies - Keep dependencies explicit and minimal
Interface-based - Depend on interfaces/abstractions, not concrete types

criteria.question: What error handling and exception strategy should be used?
criteria.outcome: Determines how errors are handled and propagated
options: Exception-based - Use exceptions for error conditions
Result/Either types - Return success/failure results explicitly
Error codes - Return error codes with results
Fail-fast - Throw exceptions immediately on errors
Graceful degradation - Handle errors gracefully with fallbacks
Language-specific patterns - Use language idioms (Python exceptions, JS promises, etc.)

criteria.question: What programming paradigm should be used?
criteria.outcome: Determines whether code follows functional, object-oriented, or hybrid patterns
options: Functional programming - Pure functions, immutability, higher-order functions, no side effects
Object-oriented programming - Classes, objects, inheritance, polymorphism, encapsulation
Hybrid approach - Combine functional and OOP patterns as appropriate
Procedural - Functions organized by feature, minimal object orientation
Data-oriented - Focus on data structures and transformations
Language-idiomatic - Follow the primary paradigm of the chosen language

criteria.question: When should properties be used versus methods?
criteria.outcome: Determines how to expose object state and behavior
options: Properties for all cases - Use properties for both data access and computed values
Properties only for data - Use properties for simple data access, methods for behavior/computation
Methods preferred - Use methods for most access, properties only for simple field access
Computed properties - Use properties for computed values that are cheap and have no side effects
Language conventions - Follow language-specific conventions (Python @property, C# properties, etc.)
No properties - Use methods exclusively, no property accessors
